A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.

Explanation: The definition of the least common multiple (LCM) involves the concept of divisibility within a set $R$. Specifically, an element $v$ is the LCM of elements $x_1, ..., x_n$ in $R$ if it satisfies two conditions: (i) each $x_i$ divides $v$, and (ii) $v$ divides any other common multiple $a$ of the $x_i$s. This definition inherently relies on the notion of divisibility, which is a binary relation, not a binary operation. It does not require a law of composition, which is a binary operation defined on pairs of elements from a set that results in another element from the same set. The law of composition is related to operations like addition or multiplication, but these operations are not necessary to define or understand the concept of divisibility or the LCM. Therefore, the concept of a law of composition is not needed for the definition of the least common multiple to make sense.
